chapter.title: &dashboard;
chapter.para: The &dashboard; is a module that adds a built-in Web based monitoring and administration application to the &mgr; (refer to for more details on &mgr;). You no longer need to know complex &ceph; related commands to manage and monitor your &ceph; cluster. You can either use the &dashboard;'s intuitive Web interface, or its built-in REST API.

sect1.title: Initial Manual Configuration
sect1.para: This section introduces information that will help you do the initial setup so that you can enjoy the &dashboard;'s Web interface while managing your cluster.

sect2.para: All HTTP connections to the dashboard are secured with SSL/TLS by default. A secure connection requires an SSL certificate. You can either use a self-signed certificate, or generate a certificate and let a well known certificate authority (CA) sign it.

tip.para: You may want to disable the SSL support for a specific reason. For example if the dashboard is running behind a proxy that does not support SSL.

sect2.title: Host Name and Port Number
sect2.para: The &dashboard; Web application binds to a specific TCP/IP address and TCP port. By default the currently active &mgr; that hosts the dashboard binds to TCP port 8443 (or 8080 when SSL is disabled).

The dashboard Web application binds to "::" by default, which corresponds to all available IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. You can change the IP address and port number of the Web application so that they apply to all &mgr; instances by using the following commands:
sect2.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph config set mgr mgr/dashboard/server_addr IP_ADDRESS &prompt.cephuser;ceph config set mgr mgr/dashboard/server_port PORT_NUMBER

tip.title: Configure &mgr; Instances Separately
tip.para: Since each ceph-mgr daemon hosts its own instance of the dashboard, you may need to configure them separately. Change the IP address and port number for a specific manager instance by using the following commands (replaace NAME with the ID of the ceph-mgr instance):
tip.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph config set mgr mgr/dashboard/NAME/server_addr IP_ADDRESS &prompt.cephuser;ceph config set mgr mgr/dashboard/NAME/server_port PORT_NUMBER

tip.title: List Configured Endpoints
tip.para: The ceph mgr services command displays all endpoints that are currently configured. Look for the 'dashboard' key to obtain the URL for accessing the dashboard.

sect2.title: Enable &sso;
sect2.para: &sso; (SSO) is an access control method that enables users to log in with a single ID and password to multiple applications simultaneously.

The &dashboard; supports external authentication of users via the SAML 2.0 protocol. Because authorization is still performed by the Dashboard, you first need to create user accounts and associate them with the desired roles. However, the authentication process can be performed by an existing Identity Provider (IdP).
To configure &sso;, use the following command:
sect2.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph dashboard sso setup saml2 CEPH_DASHBOARD_BASE_URL \ IDP_METADATA IDP_USERNAME_ATTRIBUTE \ IDP_ENTITY_ID SP_X_509_CERT \ SP_PRIVATE_KEY
sect2.para: Parameters:

listitem.para: Base URL where &dashboard; is accessible (for example 'https://cephdashboard.local').
URL, file path, or content of the IdP metadata XML (for example 'https://myidp/metadata').
Optional. Attribute that will be used to get the user name from the authentication response. Defaults to 'uid'.
Optional. Use when more than one entity ID exists on the IdP metadata.
Optional. File path or content of the certificate that will be used by &dashboard; (Service Provider) for signing and encryption.

sect1.title: Managing Users and Roles on the Command Line
sect1.para: This section describes how to manage user accounts used by the &dashboard;. It helps you create or modify user accounts, as well as set proper user roles and permissions.

sect2.title: User Accounts
sect2.para: &dashboard; supports managing multiple user accounts. Each user account consists of a username, a password (stored in encrypted form using bcrypt), an optional name, and an optional email address.
User accounts are stored in &mon;’s configuration database and are globally shared across all &mgr; instances.

sect2.title: User Roles and Permissions
sect2.para: This section describes what security scopes you can assign to a user role, how to manage user roles and assign them to user accounts.

sect3.title: Security Scopes
sect3.para: User accounts are associated with a set of roles that define which dashboard topic the user can access. The dashboard topics are grouped within a security scope. Security scopes are predefined and static. The following security scopes are currently available:

sect2.title: Reverse Proxies
sect2.para: If you are accessing the dashboard via a reverse proxy configuration, you may need to service it under a URL prefix. To get the dashboard to use hyperlinks that include your prefix, you can set the url_prefix setting:
Then you can access the dashboard at http://HOST_NAME:PORT_NUMBER/URL_PREFIX/.

sect2.title: Auditing
sect2.para: The &dashboard;'s REST API can log PUT, POST and DELETE requests to the &ceph; audit log. Logging is disabled by default, but you can enable it with the following command:
If enabled, the following parameters are logged per each request:

listitem.para: The origin of the request, for example 'https://[::1]:44410'.
The REST API path, for example '/api/auth'.
'PUT', 'POST' or 'DELETE'.
The name of the user (or ‘None’).

sect2.para: An example log entry looks like this:
sect2.screen: 2019-02-06 10:33:01.302514 mgr.x [INF] [DASHBOARD] \ from='https://[::ffff:127.0.0.1]:37022' path='/api/rgw/user/exu' method='PUT' \ user='admin' params='{"max_buckets": "1000", "display_name": "Example User", "uid": "exu", "suspended": "0", "email": "user@example.com"}'

On the dashboard login screen, enter the name and password related to the user account you already created. See for more details.
The dashboard user interface is graphically divided into several blocks: the utility menu, the main menu, and the main content pane.

sect2.title: Utility Menu
sect2.para: The top right part of the screen occupies a utility menu. It includes general tasks related more to the dashboard than to the &ceph; cluster. By clicking its items, you can access the following topics:

listitem.para: Change the language of the dashboard's user interface. You can choose from the Czech, English, German, Spanish, French, Portuguese, Chinese, or Indonesian language.
Display a list of &ceph; related tasks that are running in the background.
View and erase recent dashboard's notifications.
Display a list of links that refer to the information about the dashboard, its complete documentation, and overview of its REST API.
Manage dashboard's users and user roles. Refer to for more detailed command line description.
Sign you out of the dashboard.

sect2.title: Main Menu
sect2.para: The main dashboard's menu occupies the top left part of the screen. It covers the following topics:

listitem.para: Return to the &dashboard;'s home page.
View detailed information about overall cluster configuration and &crushmap;, its hosts, &osd;s, &mon;s, and the content of a log file.
View and manage cluster pools.
Vie and manage block devices and their &iscsi; exports.
View and manage &ganesha; deployments.
View and manage &cephfs;s.
View and manage &ogw;'s daemons, users, and buckets.

sect2.title: The Content Pane
sect2.para: The content pane occupies the main part of the dashboard's screen. The dashboard home page shows plenty of helpful widgets to inform you briefly about the current status of the cluster, capacity, and performance information.

sect2.para: Each dashboard widget shows specific status information related to a specific aspect of a running &ceph; cluster. Some widgets are active links and after clicking them, they will redirect you to a related detailed page of the topic they represent.

tip.title: More Details on Mouse Over

sect1.title: Viewing Cluster Internals
sect1.para: The Cluster menu item lets you view detailed information about &ceph; cluster hosts, OSDs, MONs, &crushmap;, and the content of log files.

sect2.title: Cluster Nodes
sect2.para: Click ClusterHosts to view a list of cluster nodes.
Click a node name in the Hostname column to view performance details of the node.
The Services column lists all daemons that are running on each related node. Click a daemon name to view its detailed configuration.

sect2.title: &mon;s
sect2.para: Click ClusterMonitors to view a list of cluster nodes with running &ceph; monitors. The list includes each monitor's rank number, public IP address, and number of open sessions.
The list is divided into two tables: one for &mon;s that are in quorum, and the second one for &mon;s that are not in quorum.
Click a node name in the Name column to view the related &mon; configuration.
The Status table shows general statistics about the running &mon;s.

sect2.title: &osd;s
sect2.para: Click ClusterOSDs to view a list of nodes with running OSD daemons/disks. The list includes each node's name, status, number of placement groups, size, usage, reads/writes chart in time, and the rate of read/write operations per second.
Click Set Cluster-wide Flags in the table heading to pop up a window with a list of flags that apply to the whole cluster. You can activate or deactivate individual flags, and confirm with Submit.

Click Set Cluster-wide Recovery Priority to in the table heading to pop up a window with a list of OSD recovery priorities that apply to the whole cluster. You can activate the preferred priority profile, and fine tune the individual values below. Confirm with Submit.

Click a node name in the Host column to view an extended table with details about the OSD setting and performance. Browsing through several tabs, you can see lists of Attributes, Metadata, Performance counter, and a graphical Histogram of reads and writes.

tip.title: Perform Specific Tasks on OSDs
tip.para: After you click an OSD node name, its table row changes color slightly meaning that you can now perform a task on the node. Click the down arrow in the top left of the table heading and select a task to perform, such as Deep Scrub. Optionally enter a required value for the task, and confirm to run it on the node.

sect2.title: Cluster Configuration
sect2.para: Click ClusterConfiguration to view a complete list of &ceph; cluster configuration options. The list contains name of the option, its short description, and current and default value.

Click on a specific option row to highlight and see detailed information about the option, such as its type of value, minimal and maximal permitted value, whether it can be updated at runtime, and many more.
After highlighting a specific option, you can edit its value(s) by clicking the Edit button in the top left of the table heading. Confirm changes with Save.

sect2.title: &crushmap;
sect2.para: Click ClusterCRUSH map to view a &crushmap; of the cluster. For more general information on &crushmap;s, refer to .
Click the root, nodes, or individual OSDs to view more detailed information, such as crush weight, depth in the map tree, device class of the OSD, and many more.

sect2.title: Manager Modules
sect2.para: Click ClusterManager modules to view a list of available &mgr; modules. Each line consists of a module name and information whether it is currently enabled or not.

After highlighting a specific module, you can see its detailed settings in the Details table below. Edit them by clicking the Edit button in the top left of the table heading. Confirm changes with Update.

sect2.title: Logs
sect2.para: Click ClusterLogs to view a list of cluster's recent log entries. Each line consists of a time stamp, type of the log entry, and logged message itself.
Click the Audit Logs tab to view log entries of the auditing subsystem. Refer to for commands to enable or disable auditing.

sect3.title: Editing &iscsi; Targets
sect3.para: To edit an existing &iscsi; target, click its row in the Targets table and click Edit in the top left of the table.
You can then modify the &iscsi; target, add or delete portals, and add or delete related RBD images. You can also adjust authentication information for the gateway.

sect3.title: Deleting &iscsi; Targets

sect2.title: RBD Quality of Service (QoS)

tip.title: For More Information
tip.para: For more general information and a description of RBD QoS configuration options, refer to .

sect2.para: The QoS options can be configured on different levels.

The global configuration is at the top of the list and will be used for all newly created RBD images and for those images which do not override these values on the pool or RBD image layer. An option value specified globally can be overridden on a per-pool or per-image basis. Options specified on a pool will be applied to all RBD images of that pool, unless overriden by a configuration option set on a pool. Options specified on an image will override options specified on a pool and will override options specified globally.
This way, it is possible to define defaults globally, adapt them for all RBD images of a specific pool and also override the pool configuration for individual RBD images.

sect3.title: Configuring options globally
sect3.para: To configure RBD options globally, select Cluster> in the menu and click Configuration.

To list all available global configuration options, click Level and select Advanced. Then filter the results of the table by filtering for "rbd_qos" in the search field. This will list all available configuration options for QoS. To change an options' value, click its row in the table first, then click Edit at the top left of the table to open the edit dialog. The edit dialog contains six different fields for specifying values. The RBD configuration option values require to be set on the mgr input field. Please note, that unlike the other dialogs, this dialog does not allow you to specify the value in convenient units. You will have to set those values in either bytes or IOPS, depending on the option you are editing.

sect3.title: Configuring options on a new pool
sect3.para: To create a new pool and configure RBD configuration options on it, click Pools, then click Create. Select replicated as "Pool type". You will then need to add the rbd application tag to the pool, to be able to configure the RBD QoS options.

note.para: It is not possible to configure RBD QoS configuration options on an erasure coded pool! To configure the RBD QoS options for erasure coded pools, you will have to edit the replicated metadata pool of an RBD image. The configuration will then be applied to the erasure coded data pool of that image.

sect3.title: Configuring options on an existing pool
sect3.para: To configure RBD QoS options on an existing pool, click Pools, then click the pools' row in the table and click Edit at the top left of the table to open the edit dialog.
You should see the "RBD Configuration" Section in the dialog, followed by a Quality of Service section.

note.para: If you neither see the "RBD Configuration", nor the "Quality of Service" section, you are likely either editing an *erasure coded* pool, which cannot be used to set RBD configuration options, or the pool isn't configured to be used by RBD images. In case of the latter, click the pencil to the right of the "Applications" label to add the rbd application tag to the pool. Immediately afterwards, the corresponding configuration sections should show up.

sect3.title: Configuration Options
sect3.para: Click "Quality of Service +" to expand the configuration options. A list of all available options will show up. The units of the configuration options are already shown in the input fields. In case of any bytes per second (BPS) option, you are free to use values like "1M" or "5G". They will automatically be converted to "1 MB/s" and "5 GB/s" respectively.
By clicking on reset button to the right of each input field, any value set on the *pool* will be removed. This does not remove configuration values of options configured globally or on an RBD image.

sect3.title: Creating RBD QoS options with a new RBD image
sect3.para: To create an RBD image with RBD QoS options set on that image, click Block, then Images and lastly Create. By clicking on Advanced the advanced configuration section will expand. Click on Quality of Service to open all available configuration options.

sect3.title: Editing RBD QoS options on existing images
sect3.para: To edit RBD QoS options on an existing image, click Block, Images, then click the pools' row in the table and lastly click Edit. The edit dialog will show up. By clicking on Advanced the advanced configuration section will expand. Click on Quality of Service to open all available configuration options.

sect3.title: Changing configuration options when copying or cloning images
sect3.para: If an RBD image is cloned or copied, the values set on that particular image will, by default, be copied, too. If you want to change them while copying or cloning, you can do so by specifying the updated configuration values in the copy/clone dialog, just like you would when creating or editing an RBD image. Doing so will only set (or reset) the values for that RBD image to be copied or cloned. Neither will the source RBD image configuration be changed, nor the global configuration.

If you choose to reset the option value on copying/cloning, no value for that option will be set on that image. This means any value of that option specified for the parent pool will be used, if the parent pools has a value configured. Otherwise, the global default will be used.

sect1.title: Managing &ganesha;

tip.title: More Information on &ganesha;
tip.para: For more general information about &ganesha;, refer to .

sect1.para: To list all available NFS exports, click NFS from the main menu.
The list shows each export's directory, daemon host name, type of storage back-end, and access type.
To view more detailed information about an NFS export, click its table row in the table.

sect2.title: Adding NFS Exports
sect2.para: To add a new NFS export, click Add in the top left of the exports table and enter the required information.

step.para: Select one or more &ganesha; daemons that will run the export.
Select a storage back-end—either CephFS or Object Gateway.
Select a user ID and other back-end related options.
Enter the directory path for the NFS export. If the directory does not exist on the server, it will be created.
Specify other NFS related options, such as supported NFS protocol version, pseudo, access type, squashing, or transport protocol.
If you need to limit access to specific clients only, click Add clients and add their IP addresses together with access type and squashing options.
Confirm with Submit.

sect2.title: Deleting NFS Exports
sect2.para: To delete an export, click its table row and select Delete in the top left of the exports table.

sect2.title: Editing NFS Exports
sect2.para: To edit an existing export, either click its table row and click Edit in the top left of the exports table.
You can then adjust all the details of the NFS export.

tip.title: For More Information
tip.para: To find detailed information about &cephfs;, refer to .

sect2.title: Viewing &cephfs; Overview
sect2.para: Click Filesystems from the main menu to view the overview of configured file systems. The main table shows each file system's name, date of creation, and whether it is enabled or not.
By clicking on a file system's table row, you reveal details about its rank and pools added to the file system.
At the bottom of the screen, you can see statistics counting number of the related MDS inodes and client requests, collected in time.

tip.title: More Information on &ogw;
tip.para: For more general information about &ogw;, refer to .

sect2.title: Viewing &ogw;s
sect2.para: To view a list of configured &ogw;s, click Object GatewayDaemons. The list includes the ID of the gateway, host name of the cluster node where the gateway daemon is running, and the gateway's version number.
Click a gateway's table row to view detailed information about the gateway. The Performance Counters tab shows details about read/write operations and cache statistics.

sect2.title: Managing &ogw; Users
sect2.para: Click Object GatewayUsers to view a list of existing &ogw; users.
Click a user's table row to view details about the user account, such as status information or the user and bucket quota details.

sect3.title: Adding a New Gateway User
sect3.para: To add a new gateway user, click Add in the top left of the table heading. Fill in their credentials, details about the S3 key and user/bucket quota, then confirm with Add.

sect3.title: Deleting Gateway Users
sect3.para: To delete a gateway user, click its table row and select Delete in the top left of the table heading. Activate the Yes, I am sure check-box and confirm with Delete User.

sect3.title: Editing Gateway Users Details
sect3.para: To change gateway user details, click the user's table row and select Edit in the top left of the table heading.
Modify basic or additional user information, such as their capabilities, keys, subusers, and quota information. Confirm with Update.

The Keys tab includes a read-only list of gateway's users and their access and secret keys. To view the keys, click a user name in the list and then select Show in the top left of the table heading. In the S3 Key dialog box, click the 'eye' icon to unveil the keys, or click the clipboard icon to copy the related key to the clipboard.

sect2.title: Managing the &ogw; Buckets
sect2.para: &ogw; (OGW) buckets implement the functionality of &ostack; &swift; containers. &ogw; buckets serve as containers for storing data objects.
Click Object GatewayBuckets to view a list of OGW buckets.

sect3.title: Adding a New Bucket
sect3.para: To add a new OGW bucket, click Add in the top left of the table heading. Enter the bucket's name and select its owner. Confirm with Add.

sect3.title: Viewing Bucket Details
sect3.para: To view detailed information about an OGW bucket, click its table row.

tip.title: Bucket Quota
tip.para: Below the Details table, you can find details about the bucket quota settings.

sect3.title: Updating the Owner of a Bucket
sect3.para: Click a bucket table row, then select Edit in the top left of the table heading.
Update the owner of the bucket and confirm with Update.

sect3.title: Deleting a Bucket
sect3.para: To delete an OGW bucket, click its table row and select Delete in the top left of the table heading. Activate the Yes, I am sure check box, and confirm with Delete bucket.
